content: Iraq War Vet to Sponsor DADT Repeal April 09, 2009 Rep. Patrick Murphy will reportedly be taking over sponsorship of legislation to repeal "don't ask, don't tell" in the House, according to Roll Call . Sources familiar with the situation have told The Advocate the same information, but Rep. Murphy's office has not yet confirmed the news. Murphy, an Iraq War veteran and member of the House Armed Services Committee, emerged as a critical player during the very first hearing on the matter, which was held last summer. "You're saying you don't trust our military professionals to serve openly with people who might be different," Murphy said indignantly to Elaine Donnelly, president of the Center for Military Readiness, a right-wing organization that advocates for maintaining the policy as well as putting restrictions on women serving in the military. "I think that's an insult," Murphy added. Full article here > >http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid78342.asp Personally I am very pleased to learn of this and feel it will add yet another powerful voice of reason and truth to counter the misinformation and lies that come from Elaine Donnelly and those like her.

title: Iraq War Vet to Sponsor DADT Repeal

content: I too am pleased to hear Mr. Murphy is considering taking over sponsorship of this legislation. He is a well respected Veteran of the Iraq war and holds more clout on Military matters than a civilian would.
reply: I too am pleased to hear Mr. Murphy is considering taking over sponsorship of this legislation. He is a well respected Veteran of the Iraq war and holds more clout on Military matters than a civilian would.
title: Iraq War Vet to Sponsor DADT Repeal

content: quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: Iraq War Vet to Sponsor DADT Repeal April 09, 2009 Rep. Patrick Murphy will reportedly be taking over sponsorship of legislation to repeal "don't ask, don't tell" in the House, according to Roll Call . Sources familiar with the situation have told The Advocate the same information, but Rep. Murphy's office has not yet confirmed the news. Murphy, an Iraq War veteran and member of the House Armed Services Committee, emerged as a critical player during the very first hearing on the matter, which was held last summer. "You're saying you don't trust our military professionals to serve openly with people who might be different," Murphy said indignantly to Elaine Donnelly, president of the Center for Military Readiness, a right-wing organization that advocates for maintaining the policy as well as putting restrictions on women serving in the military. "I think that's an insult," Murphy added. Full article here > >http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid78342.asp Personally I am very pleased to learn of this and feel it will add yet another powerful voice of reason and truth to counter the misinformation and lies that come from Elaine Donnelly and those like her. As a veteran myself, I think I can safely say without denigrating us that....the VAST majority of military members are NOT....'professionals.' The vast majority are made up of enlistees who have NO intention of making the military their career. Therefore, Murphy's indignant remark was....OFF the mark. Instead, he needs to recognize that the vast majority of us simply enlisted to serve our country, obtain some training and separate to take advantage of our VA benefits.

The vast majority are made up of enlistees who have NO intention of making the military their career. Therefore, Murphy's indignant remark was....OFF the mark. content: Responding to: 19022583 Thread: Iraq War Vet to Sponsor DADT Repeal Date/Time: Sat 11 April 2009 08:33 AM (Pacific) quote: Originally posted by 19022583: As a veteran myself, I think I can safely say without denigrating us that....the VAST majority of military members are NOT....’professionals.’ The vast majority are made up of enlistees who have NO intention of making the military their career. Therefore, Murphy’s indignant remark was....OFF the mark. Instead, he needs to recognize that the vast majority of us simply enlisted to serve our country, obtain some training and separate to take advantage of our VA benefits. It’s such a shame that you got yourself suspended. And to think you did it yourself, with no help from anyone else! Now I beg to vigorously differ with your opinion that “the VAST majority of military members are NOT.... ‘professionals.’” Absolutely not true! While there may not be too many career military, with the exception of a tiny percentage of dirtbags, all military members are, indeed, “professionals!” I’m sorry that you didn’t consider yourself a “professional” when you were in. This message has been edited. Last edited by: DaleU, Sat 11 April 2009 07:43 PM
